body.p:
Since Mr. Marcusson
has honored me with the perusal of the contents of your
letter, I take the liberty to say, that we need not
at all be surprised at the false assertions of Bonahan
or any of his colleagues in the fabrication of falshoods
in regard to their pretended invasion into Judaism.
The knowledge I have obtained on various occasions of men
of their stamp, has taught me sufficiently that protes-
tantic jesuitism is existing to a great extent, among
a class of man who render the name of a society for
the purpose of ameliorating the condition of the jews
send many idlers abroad, among them a few renegades
from our holy religion, who are to lazy to work for an
honest living. (We can easily spare them as the prophet says
Hebrew). These men are ever ready and so very eager
to bounce upon every word uttered by an unsuspecting man
especially when he happens not to be familiar with the
language, to construe this to their purpose, than to publish
it with so many embellishments and fabulus ideas of their own
begetting, as to make it very interesting to the ear of their
bigotted emploiers. A matter of fact only lately occurred
to miself, will serve to illustrate the above. As man
calling himself Avery from New York state and travelling

as he stated for the above named society, called on me
and after having taken the trouble twice to converse with
him on religion, he felt so fully defeated, that although
he promised to call again, he never did so. I saw him
walking the streets frequently after that, and I was told
by the minister of the fifth presbiterian church*, that he
preached the Sunday following our arguments at his
church, were he stated, that he visited some of the jews
in this city, that he found them very intelligent, and that
he entertained great hopes soon to bring them to the
knowledge of divine truth. He has not even been listened
to what his mission was, by any other jew in this city, and
as to the truth of the effects of my arguments, as above said
I will bring christians who were present at the time to tes-
tify to the same. This and similar facts with what I know
of Mr. M. up to this day, leads me to suppose that those
Sharks after paying him what they had agreed upon, to
compensate his soils in giving them hebrew lessons, they ende-
vor to represent this as a bribe to induce the above said
Gentln to change his religion. Now miself and many others
here will prove that he regards money to little ever to
fall a victim to such a snare. I have ascertained
that he has instructed those men for nearly four months
every day except Saturday & Sunday—for the small pittance
of 70 Dollars, and now it appears, since they full well knew
that their stupid minds would not pick up sufficient
hebrew an equevalence for their so much spoken of ?,
they had a more jesuitic aim in view in regard to Mr M.
but since they did not succeed, they try to revenge

themselves, by proclaiming to the world the flattering
hope of the conversion of a Rabby.

The position of these men, and especially that of Mr Bonahan
is actually very deplorable. The latter gentln although I have
no personal knowledge of, I still have received such
a description of his character by a very eminent christian
a Gentln of great learning and thorough knowledge
to guarrantee my supposition, that we may rely as much
on his assertions, as on those of any other Hebrew.

What most surprised me was that, Mr. M. condescended
even to take the least notice of the slanderous productions
of a parcel of man, who for money collected or almost-
extorted, from the blind industrious portion of the community,
pretend to undertake, to ameliorate the condition of a nation,
who because being least, had ever to submit to all sorts
of persecutions; at the same time losing intirely sight
of the great defects existing among their own people.
Considering them cristians, because they curse & swear by
the name of Crist. Who needs conversion?
Surely no man of sense! Besides can pecuniary
inducements convert a man? She will say no!
Then why did these men of Montgomery promiz him such
a glorious future of indolence and opulence, if he would
only to consent to stay with them, by which means they
supposed to produce a rupture between him and his
people? Why bring those by Mr. M. so hard earned paltry
70 Dollars so emphatically into consideration. For my part
I am so well aquainted with these petty manoevers such
as invitations to prayer meetings, and other apparent brotherly

treatments and even lies to effect their purpose.
But not every body can comprehend their motives.

Let us cast a look into the dissensions of their own
churches where nothing but love is taught but not prac-
tised, with plenty of brothers and sisters on their tongue
but none in their hearts, and then look at the ?
friendly face of the missionary, and we cannot mistake
the hipocrite.

Their attempt to injure Mr Ms character as a Rabby is
to bottomless, to cause him any fear.
I would refer him to Deut. 7.17.18.

If my time as a business man would only permit me I
could tell many things which have come under my
notice, as well in this country as in england.

I hope the above will suffice at present, and
I think that the public may be benefitted by reading
the words of Alether.

I hope Mr Leeser that you may grant it a space in your
valuable paper as far as you may consider proper.
The truth of all I said I can establish by living wittnesses,
and as Mr. Marcusson has not sufficient power of the English
language, I thought to do no more than my duty in
defending him against Hebrew. This latter expression
I have also used above, since I know they consider it
the greatest insult.
